newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada Sept consumer prices rise 1.5 pct on year.
newsitem.headline: Canada Sept consumer prices rise 1.5 pct on year.

text.p: Canada's unadjusted September consumer price index rose 0.1 percent in the month and 1.5 percent in the year to 135.9, Statistics Canada said Tuesday.
CONSUMER PRICES - Pct chg Sept Aug
Unadjusted ex food and energy mth/mth +0.1 +0.1
Unadjusted ex food and energy yr/yr +1.2 +1.3

A Reuters survey of economists had forecast the seasonally adjusted CPI to rise 0.3 percent on the month and the undadjusted CPI to rise 0.1 percent on the month. The survey also forecast a 1.4 percent rise in the all-items and a 1.3 percent rise in the core CPI.
Statistics Canada said higher prices for new vehicles, gasoline, university tuition fees, telephone services and processed meat accounted for most of the annual increase.
Large decreases in the cost of mortgage loans, new houses, beef and fresh vegetables offset part of the gains.
University tuition fees jumped an average 11.8 percent in September, with the largest increase in Ontario, where tuition rose by 20 percent in the month.
Gasoline prices rose 1.4 percent in September from August and 3.7 percent from the same month a year earlier.
Prices of clothing and footwear rose an average 0.9 percent in September.
Food prices fell by 0.3 percent in September from August.

Traveller accommodation charges fell 5.6 percent in the month as fall rates were introduced at some hotels. Air fares fell by 3.5 percent in September due to seasonally lower fares for many domestic and international routes.
(For further information from Statistics Canada, contact Sandra Shadlock, Prices Division, 613-951-9606.)
